document.masterDocTitle: Redefinition of the millipede subgenus Megaphyllum sensu stricto Verhoeff, 1894 and neotype designation for Megaphyllum austriacum (Latzel, 1884) (Myriapoda: Diplopoda: Julida: Julidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redefinition of the millipede subgenus Megaphyllum sensu stricto Verhoeff, 1894 and neotype designation for Megaphyllum austriacum (Latzel, 1884) (Myriapoda: Diplopoda: Julida: Julidae)

heading.emphasis:
Key to males of subgenus
Megaphyllum
sensu
stricto
on the basis of gonopod characters and body colour patterns

paragraph.keyLead: - Anterior process ( ap ) reduced to a low ridge or fully absent................................................... 5
- Posterior process ( pp ) longer or subequal to solenomere...................................................... 4

3 Anterior process ( ap ) perpendicular to the main opisthomere body, with toothed apex (
Fig. 5 d
)..............
M. silvaticum

- Anterior ( ap ) process parallel to the main opisthomere body, with normal blunt apex (
Figs 4 d, 4 f
)...........
M. projectum

4 Posterior solenomere process ( psp ) large, massive, standing high above the anterior solenomere process ( asp ) (
Fig. 2 d
). Dark grey animals with very wide reddish longitudinal band.........................................
M. erythronotum

5 Apical anterior hump ( ah ) well developed into a more or less blunt protuberance in front of the anterior solenomere process ( asp )............................................................................................... 6

6 Promere with a unique rod-like process below its apex (
Fig. 14 c
). Dark grey animals with two bright dorsal longitudinal bands; uniformly dark forms also present........................................................
M. transsylvanicum

- Posterior process ( pp ) joining the main opisthomere body at a more acute angle of not more than 20 ˚– 30 ˚. Promere more grad- ually narrowing..................................................................................... 8

8 Posterior process ( pp ) shorter than solenomere (
Fig. 16 d
). Uniformly dark brown animals without longitudinal lines...............................................................................................
M. rhodopinum

9 Anterior solenomere process ( asp ) more than two times longer than the posterior solenomere process ( psp ) (
Fig. 19 d
). Plain brownish animals............................................................................
M. tauricum
11 Anterior solenomere process ( asp ) strongly elongated, surpassing by far the posterior solenomere process ( psp )......... 12

12 Posterior process ( pp ) subequal to solenomere, apically serrated, as the anterior solenomere process ( asp ) (
Fig. 14 d
*). Dark grey animals with two yellowish dorsal longitudinal bands............................................
M. kievense
13 Posterior solenomere process ( psp ) much longer and wider than the anterior solenomere process ( asp )................ 14

15 Posterior solenomere process ( psp ) swan-neck shaped; posterior process ( pp ) higher than solenomere (
Fig. 8 d
)....................................................................................................
M. cygniforme

16 Posterior solenomere process ( psp ) wavy (
Fig. 11 d
). Uniformly dark brown animals...................
M. montivagum

- Posterior solenomere process ( psp ) smooth (
Fig. 10 d
).............................................
M. glossulifer
- Posterior process ( pp ) shorter or subequal to solenomere..................................................... 19

19 Posterior process ( pp ) wide and rounded; anterior and posterior solenomere processes ( asp and psp ) slender, finger-like (
Fig. 15 d
). Very large dark grey animals with narrow, yellow to reddish longitudinal dorsal band..................
M. hercules

- Posterior process ( pp ) narrow, apically pointed; anterior and posterior solenomere processes ( asp and psp ) rather short, weakly protruding (Fig. 6 d)........................................................................
M. austriacum
